paper_title.ja: Isometric muscle contractions voluntarily synchronized with one-minute oscillations in postural sway improve orthostatic tolerance (共著)
paper_title.en: Isometric Muscle Contractions Voluntarily Synchronized with One-minute Oscillation in Postural Sway Improve Orthostatic Tolerance :

description.ja: INAMURA, K., MANO, T.and IWASE, S.Isometric Muscle Contractions Voluntarily Synchronized with One-minute Oscillations in Postural Sway Improve Orthostatic Tolerance.Adv.Exerc.Sports Physiol., Vol.5 No.4 pp.89-100, 1999. We examined effects of voluntary isometric muscle contractions in the calves and/or abdomen on orthostatic tolerance. Thirty-four healthy young males aged 18 to 24 years were requested to maintain a quiet upright standing position in order to examine three kinds of standing maneuvers. Experimental standing was characterized by repetitive voluntary muscle contractions in the legs and/or abdomen synchronized with one-minute oscillations in phase with natural muscle contractions derived from postural sway. Control standing included no voluntary muscle contractions and as little movement as possible. Stroke volume(SV), heart rate, and cardiac output(CO)were measured by impedance plethysmography during the standing. Blood pressure was measured by an auto-sphygmomanometer. The front-back sway was measured by platform stabilometry with electromyograms of leg and trunk muscles to confirm their synchronization with the postural sway. The standing maneuver using calf muscle contractions elevated diastolic blood pressure(DBP)(6.9±1.7%, P<0.01)in the subjects of the synchronous group. However, the maneuver decreased SV(6.7 ± 2.5%, P<0.05)in the subjects of the asynchronous group. The maneuver using abdominal muscle contractions elevated DBP(8.6 ± 3.4%, P<0.05)and mean blood pressure(MBP)(6.6 ± 1.9%, P<0.01)in the synchronous group. The maneuver using leg and abdominal muscle contractions increased SV(4.0 ± 1.8%)and CO(11.2 ± 5.5%)in the synchronous group, but the increase was not statistically significant. This maneuver also elevated DBP(9.0 ± 2.6%, P<0.01)and MBP(5.0 ± 1.4%, P<0.05)in the synchronous group. In the asynchronous group, the same maneuver elevated systolic blood pressure(10.3 ± 3.1%, P<0.05), DBP(15.0 ± 5.1%, P<0.05), and MBP(10.3 ± 3.1%, P<0.05)and increased total peripheral resistance(13.0 ± 3.9%, P<0.05). We concluded that alternating voluntary muscle contractions in the calves and lower abdomen synchronized with one-minute oscillations in postural sway are efficacious in improving orthostatic tolerance during quiet upright standing. This maneuver may be useful as a countermeasure for syncopal or fainting episodes induced by prolonged quiet standing in humans.

paper_title.ja: One-minute wave in body fluid volume change enhanced by postural sway during upright standing. (共著)
paper_title.en: One-minute wave in body fluid volume change enhanced by postural sway during upright standing

description.en: To analyze how the 1-min oscillation in postural sway and 1-min wave in body fluid volume change contribute to human circulatory homeostasis, several levels of body circumference, foot pressure center, electromyograms, and volumes of the leg, abdomen, and thorax were measured during upright standing for 40 min in 20 healthy young men. Spectral analyses of these parameters revealed that a 1-min rhythm is found in all parameters and that the 1-min wave in body fluid volume changes in the lower leg, which occur in fluid pooling caused by gravity, propagate upward. Muscle pumping in the lower leg triggered by the postural sway was found to increase the power of this 1-min wave. A quantitative analysis of body circumferences disclosed that the 1-min wave in body fluid volume change compensates for gravitational downward fluid shift, with the volume of 6.3 +/- 5.0 ml/cycle at the heart level. We concluded that a coupling mechanism between the 1-min oscillation in postural sway and the upward propagation of 1-min wave in body fluid volume change contributes to maintain systemic blood pressure during upright standing in humans.

paper_title.en: One-minute wave in body fluid volume change enhanced by postural sway during upright standing

description.en: To analyze how the 1-min oscillation in postural sway and 1-min wave in body fluid volume change contribute to human circulatory homeostasis, several levels of body circumference, foot pressure center, electromyograms, and volumes of the leg, abdomen, and thorax were measured during upright standing for 40 min in 20 healthy young men. Spectral analyses of these parameters revealed that a 1-min rhythm is found in all parameters and that the 1-min wave in body fluid volume changes in the lower leg, which occur in fluid pooling caused by gravity, propagate upward. Muscle pumping in the lower leg triggered by the postural sway was found to increase the power of this 1-min wave. A quantitative analysis of body circumferences disclosed that the 1-min wave in body fluid volume change compensates for gravitational downward fluid shift, with the volume of 6.3 +/- 5.0 ml/cycle at the heart level. We concluded that a coupling mechanism between the 1-min oscillation in postural sway and the upward propagation of 1-min wave in body fluid volume change contributes to maintain systemic blood pressure during upright standing in humans.
